title: Subdivisions
historical_context: This article is part of the Vicious Circle Trilogy, exploring the dynamics within the hacker and phreaker community during the late 1980s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: The article examines the proliferation of groups within the hacking and phreaking community, discussing their implications for trust, security, and law enforcement infiltration.
summary:
In 'Subdivisions', Knight Lightning delves into the myriad of groups that have emerged within the hacking and phreaking communities, highlighting the potential risks associated with group affiliations. He argues that while these groups ostensibly foster collaboration and information sharing, they can also create vulnerabilities, particularly when it comes to trust among members. The article suggests that the very act of forming groups can attract unwanted attention from law enforcement, who may perceive these affiliations as indicators of organized crime. This perception can lead to increased scrutiny and resources directed at the community, ultimately jeopardizing the privacy and security of its members.

Knight Lightning further illustrates his points by referencing specific instances of infiltration by informants within these groups, emphasizing the ease with which security agents can blend in and gather intelligence. He critiques the culture of exclusivity that often accompanies group membership, suggesting that it can foster a false sense of security among members. The article serves as a cautionary tale, urging the community to reconsider the necessity and implications of group formations, advocating instead for a more unified approach to knowledge sharing and collaboration in the face of external threats.
